text:
Broadway, west side, south from Exchange Place to Battery Place, showing the Aldrich Court at No. 41-45. Note the New York Bank Note Company in the Washington Building, No. 1 Broadway.

About 1885.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, south across Exchange Place, and showing the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange Building at the N. E. corner. This building was erected in 1887 -1888. In 1922 it was occupied by the Columbia Trust Co. The low building beyond is the Arcade Building.

About 1890

Thru New York Historical Society
Neg.# 2477, 2478

Broadway, at the N. E. corner of Exchange Place, showing the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange Building (erected in 1887-8). For details of this organization see page 792 of Kings Handbook of N. Y. (1893). The 22 story Columbia Trust Company Building succeeded to this site. On the right is an extensive view eastward on Exchange Place, across New, Broad and William Streets. Note the low buildings to the rear of this structure. These were subsequently removed for the Blair and Mackey Buildings during the building controversy between these individuals.

About 1890

Ewing Galloway

Manhattan Life Building
P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd November 13, 1945

Broadway, west side, north from and including Exchange Alley, to but not including Thames Street, showing prominently the 32 story Adams Building (No. 57-61 Broadway) at the N.W. corner of Exchange Alley.

Edwin Levick

about 1920
title: Manhattan: Broadway - Exchange Alley

text:
50-44, 42 and 34-32 Broadway, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Exchange Place, showing the 4-story Standard Arcade, No. 50-44, prior to demolition. On the extreme right appears a portion of the Custom House. No. 50 was the site of the first skyscraper, the Tower Building, a 12-story steel structure erected in 1888 and demolished in 1914. The Standard Arcade Building bore an inscription to that effect. A 36 story structure occupies this site since 1927. For further information see, The New York Sun, Saturday September 4, 1937.

1926.

Brown Brothers.

50-44 Broadway, adjoining the S.E. corner of Exchange Place, showing the Arcade Building. Prior to the erection of this structure in 1914; the 12-story Tower Building stood at No. 50. This was the first steel structure in New York and was erected in 1888.
1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway (center, street level not shown) at Exchange Place (center to right margin) and Exchange Alley (center to left border), showing 3 corners of this intersection; the southwesterly being obscured by the Exchange Court (foreground, S.E. corner). The large 32 story structure is the Adams Building and the 23, the Columbia Trust Co. Bldg. The photographer is viewing northward to Broadway from atop No. 50 Broad Street.

September 16, 1931.

P.L. Sperr

Broadway, north from Bowling Green to Exchange Alley as seen from the U.S. Custom House and across the Green.
About 1935.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Broadway - Exchange Alley

text:
Exchange Place, east from Broadway.  On the left is the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company Building.  The incline shown slopes down across New Street to Broad street where the trucks appear.

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N.Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex Allard, IRGV.

HERALD TRIBUNE EDITORIAL ART DEPT#
Adams Express Bldg.
61 Broadway
No date

NEWS ITEM FROM CHARLES F. NOYES CO., INC.

The new home of the New York State Insurance Dept., Louis H. Pink, Superintendent, will be established in this 33-story office building at 61 Broadway, as the result of a lease closed by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. Involved in the Transaction are the entire 14th Floor and part of the 15th Floor, containing about 18,PP square feet.

No date.
